item.title: Estimated Completion Date Updated (Late 2025)
item.author: The Data Liberation Project
item.description: On September 12, 2024, in response to a Data Liberation Project request for an updated timeline, the Civil Division emailed: “[â€¦] We are working diligently through our backlog. We are currently tackling requests from mid-2021. It could still take an additional year on your request. A few months ago, we brought on additional staff in an effort to tackle our backlog.”

item.title: Estimated Completion Date Provided (March 2024)
item.author: The Data Liberation Project
item.description: On March 9, 2023, in response to the DLP’s emailed request for a estimated completion date, the Civil Division wrote, “Due to our current backlog, we anticipate completion of your request by March 2024. Although we have provided a timeframe for completing your request, it is possible that your request can be completed prior to that date.”

item.title: Request Acknowledged, Placed on "Complex Track"
item.author: The Data Liberation Project
item.description: On October 5, 2022, the DOJ’s Civil Division emailed an acknowledgment letter ðŸ“„ regarding this request, which has been assigned to the “complex” processing track. “The records you seek require a search in another Office in the Division; therefore, your request presents ‘unusual circumstances’ under the FOIA,” according to the letter. The agency has agreed to classify the Data Liberation Project as a “representative of the news media,” which means the request will not incur search fees. It has not, however, “yet made a decision on your request for a [full] fee waiver.”

item.title: Request Informally Acknowledged
item.author: The Data Liberation Project
item.description: On September 30, 2022, in response to a status inquiry, the Civil Division confirmed via email that it has received this request, and that “[a]n acknowledgment letter will follow shortly.”
